page.title:
Radiation and Calibration are 8-dimensional Sampling Problems
Radiation and Calibration are 8-dimensional
Sampling Problems
page.enlisting:
• Latitude • Longitude • Altitude • Time • Solar Zenith Angle • Viewing Zenith Angle • Viewing Azimuth Angle • Wavelength • Radiance signals vary a factor of 2 to 10 with all of these dimensions. Yet key climate change is a few tenths of a percent/decade. • Climate Change adds a stealth "9th dimension": accuracy • Latitude • Longitude • Altitude • Time • Solar Zenith Angle • Viewing Zenith Angle • Viewing Azimuth Angle • Wavelength

Angle Pointing (zenith, azimuth) is required to obtain any calibration matches beyond those at nadir. Options: pointable instrument, pointing table, or S/C reaction wheels

any calibration matches beyond those at nadir. Options:
pointable instrument, pointing table, or S/C reaction wheels

page.title:
74 degree Inclination/600 km Orbit 6 months of Equator Crossing Times
74 degree Inclination/600 km Orbit
6 months of Equator Crossing Times
page.normal_text:
Solar zenith angle in color (blue high sun to red low sun)
Solar zenith angle in
color (blue high sun
to red low sun)

This orbit samples the equator at local noon 6 times per yr.
This orbit samples
the equator at local
noon 6 times per yr.

Nominal CLARREO 90 degree inclination orbit does this twice per year.
Nominal CLARREO
90 degree inclination
orbit does this twice
per year.

Inclination is max latitude seen at nadir, add 10 deg lat off nadir
Inclination is max
latitude seen at nadir,
add 10 deg lat off nadir

page.title:
How often and Where will Orbits Cross? June - Dec CLARREO calibrating Terra/Aqua/NPOESS
How often and Where will Orbits Cross? June - Dec
CLARREO calibrating Terra/Aqua/NPOESS
page.normal_text:
90 degree Incl. 1 24-hr cycle/yr
90 degree Incl. 1 24-hr cycle/yr

74 degree Incl. 3 24-hr cycles/yr
74 degree Incl. 3 24-hr cycles/yr

Conclusion: intercalibration in polar regions is common for leo satellites, tropics less common: precession cycle limits.
Conclusion: intercalibration in polar regions is common for
leo satellites, tropics less common: precession cycle limits.

page.title:
How often and Where will Orbits Cross? June - Dec CLARREO calibrating Terra/Aqua/NPOESS
How often and Where will Orbits Cross? June - Dec
CLARREO calibrating Terra/Aqua/NPOESS
page.normal_text:
90 degree Incl. 1 24-hr cycle/yr
90 degree Incl. 1 24-hr cycle/yr

74 degree Incl. 3 24-hr cycles/yr
74 degree Incl. 3 24-hr cycles/yr

Conclusion: in 6 months can cross-calibrate across the entire Range of climate regimes: equator to pole, ocean to land. But is the sampling enough?
Conclusion: in 6 months can cross-calibrate across the entire
Range of climate regimes: equator to pole, ocean to land.
But is the sampling enough?

Conclusion: Pointing capability is critical to calibrate geostationary sensors at any position other than the sub-satellite equatorial point.
Conclusion: Pointing capability is critical to calibrate geostationary
sensors at any position other than the sub-satellite equatorial point.
